title: In Search Of: Term for "Anti-Stencil"
content:
Thanks to the "Typophile Merchandise?" thread\* I've realized that letterforms that have no fully-enclosed counters can be useful (for ease of manufacturing certain things). They're like the inverse of stencil letterforms. Kind of like some of the letters here: [http://typophile.com/node/76578](http://web.archive.org/web/20130820173524/http:/typophile.com/node/76578 "http://typophile.com/node/76578")

\* [http://typophile.com/node/101919](http://web.archive.org/web/20130820173524/http:/typophile.com/node/101919 "http://typophile.com/node/101919")

What to call that?

hhp
author: hrant

comments.content: I’d go with _senza contatori_…

Mono-something something. Something like _monolithic_, emphasizing "out of a single block".  
A few random tries: "Monogram" (nah), "Monotone" (nope). "Monotype", is that taken? :)

How about "Monograph"?

(Edit) "Monobody", maybe.

Monotan? :-)

hhp
Mono-a-mono…
couterless

Counter-counter could be anti-counter.  
Fret-friendly  
Ajar counter  
Agoraphiliac  
Unit Construction
Dis-counted? Nah... gotta be something with five different incomprehensible etymologies... Lidded? Might do.

Nice stuff, guys.

But wait, isn't there a nice topological term already?

hhp
Closin' counters :-)

> But wait, isn't there a nice topological term already?

That would be [_simply connected_](http://web.archive.org/web/20130820173524/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simply_connected_space)
I'd lean to 'counterless', since that describes the phenomenon relative to standard typographic terminology for the thing that is not present.

But a "counter" doesn't have to be closed... For example a "c" is fine as-is.

Hey, what about "silhouette"?

hhp

Silhouette describes countered text too though.

It strikes me that the linked sample would actually be more balanced and less distracting if just the counters remained (maybe slightly emphasised).

Tim
What about "filled", "boundless" or, if you wish, "unpierced"? Even "blind" might do well.

To get really nerdy, " [1-connected topology](http://web.archive.org/web/20130820173524/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simply_connected_space)"

But I like "filled."

Craig, indeed sometimes the most boring thing makes the most sense.

hhp

+1

I think of it as filled too.

And when using my design software the term Fill is one of the most common actions/noun that there is.

n.

However, that name is already taken—there are some two-font typefaces designed for two-color setting, where one of the fonts is called Fill, e.g. Rosewood.

Solid?  
Holeless?

Hmmm, I guess you're right about "fill"...

And I think "solid" actually contrasts nicely with "stencil".

hhp
Unencountered

The term solid is already used in contrast to stencil or open/outline cuts in some typefaces, e.g., [Oxide Solid](http://web.archive.org/web/20130820173524/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_oxide_ot/), [Bokka](http://web.archive.org/web/20130820173524/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_bokka_ot/) and [Mona Lisa](http://web.archive.org/web/20130820173524/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/itc/itc_mona_lisa_std_complete_pack/).

_Holeless?_

In that same vein, why not “Unholy”…
Closed encounters [of the 1st kind]

I wonder...  
 [http://instagram.com/p/a8jjyMhgAt/#](http://web.archive.org/web/20130820173524/http:/instagram.com/p/a8jjyMhgAt/# "http://instagram.com/p/a8jjyMhgAt/#")  
(Thanks to James Grieshaber.)

And a related gem:  
 [https://twitter.com/hhpapazian/status/341622778270728192/photo/1](http://web.archive.org/web/20130820173524/https:/twitter.com/hhpapazian/status/341622778270728192/photo/1 "https://twitter.com/hhpapazian/status/341622778270728192/photo/1")  
(Right down the street from me.)

hhp
